DataElement.preferredName: Breast Neoplasm Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Lobular Breast Carcinoma In Situ Clinical Study Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator whether research conducted with human subjects or on material of human origin in which an investigator directly interacts with human subjects with Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ, a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts, or Lobular Breast Carcinoma In Situ, a non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Breast Neoplasm Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Lobular Breast Carcinoma In Situ Clinical Study
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to research conducted with human subjects or on material of human origin in which an investigator directly interacts with human subjects with Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ, a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts, or Lobular Breast Carcinoma In Situ, a non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant neoplasm of the breast parenchyma.  It can originate from the ducts, lobules or the breast adipose tissue.  Breast neoplasms are much more common in females than males. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant neoplasm of the breast parenchyma. It can originate from the ducts, lobules or the breast adipose tissue. Breast neoplasms are much more common in females than males.

Property.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Lobular Breast Carcinoma In Situ Clinical Study
Property.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.:A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.:Research conducted with human subjects or on material of human origin in which an investigator directly interacts with human subjects; includes development of new technologies, mechanism of human diseases, therapy, clinical trials, epidemiology, behavior and health services research.

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.

Research conducted with human subjects or on material of human origin in which an investigator directly interacts with human subjects; includes development of new technologies, study of mechanisms of human diseases, therapy, clinical trials, epidemiologic, behavior, and health services research.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the management of a research protocol and its case report forms.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.
